subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
This word was pronounced *''teŋ'' in Old Chinese, as would be expected from a {{zh-l|丁}} phonetic. By the early {{w|Ming dynasty|Ming}} period, the character had been borrowed for another word with the same meaning but a different pronunciation, without the nasal ending. This may be related to the previous reading, as a dialectal variant. In Mandarin and some other dialects, the new reading became standard; however, derivations of the older pronunciation are still used in some dialects (Wu, Min Nan), Japanese ({{m|ja|ちょう|chō}}, {{m|ja|てい|tei}}) and Vietnamese ({{m|vi|đánh}}).

Also compare {{cog|mkh-pro|*dah|*dah ~ daʔ|to hit, to meet}}, whence {{cog|mnw|ဒး||tr=tɛ̀h|to hit (a mark), meet with, reach [goal], be correct, apposite, to fit}} and {{cog|km|ទះ||to slap, to strike}}.
